Award.AwardTitle: Computational Infrastructure for the Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS) supports a diverse community of experts who model Earth surface processes. It does so by developing, supporting, and disseminating integrated software modules that predict the movement of fluids, and the flux (production, erosion, transport, and deposition) of sediment and solutes in landscapes and their sedimentary basins. CSDMS provides open-access to numerical models, maintains data for modelers and educational resources on earth science modeling for teachers, provides computing resources for members, offers help in advanced model coupling, and is a platform of discussion for earth science research.

This project aims to enhance the CSDMS cyber-infrastructure. The current CSDMS Modeling Framework will be extended for use within a web browser, on a wider variety of computational platforms, and on other high performance computing clusters to ensure robustness and sustainability of the framework. Community-generated models will be converted into ?plug-and-play? components through the development of automated wrapping tools. Methods for quantifying model uncertainty will be adapted. Benchmarking data will be incorporated into the CSDMS modeling framework to support model inter-comparison. Finally, a robust mechanism for ingesting and utilizing semantic mediation databases will also be developed within the Modeling Framework. In addition, six new community initiatives will be pursued: 1) an Earth - ecosystem modeling initiative to capture ecosystem dynamics and ensuing interactions with landscapes, 2) a geodynamics initiative to investigate the interplay among climate, geomorphology, and tectonic processes, 3) an Anthropocene modeling initiative, to incorporate mechanistic models of human influences, 4) a coastal vulnerability modeling initiative, with emphasis on deltas and their multiple threats and stressors, 5) a continental margin modeling initiative, to capture extreme oceanic and atmospheric events generating turbidity currents in the Gulf of Mexico, and 6) a CZO Focus Research Group, to develop compatibility between CSDMS architecture and protocols and Critical Zone Observatory-developed models and data.

CSDMS streamlines the computer modeling of myriad societally relevant processes, including melting glaciers, landslides, erosion, wetland evolution, water cycling, flooding, and coastal change. Through its community support mechanisms, CSDMS catalyzes the process of idea generation and hypothesis testing, enabling the rapid creation and application of models tailored to specific settings, scientific problems, and time scales. CSDMS? community approach allows the efficient development of models that are more powerful than could be developed by any single group ? redundancy is reduced, models are better vetted, the capability for innovation is expanded, and energy can be focused towards earth-surface domains that are poorly represented or controversial. CSDMS ensures that models are accessible and transparent by soliciting and publishing model documentation. Staff at the CSDMS Integration Facility convert models into modules that can be easily coupled together; this modularity gives rise to new applications for existing software. This new award will enable CSDMS to enhance its cyber-infrastructure by developing: 1) software products and approaches designed to be accessible, easy to use, and relevant, 2) new community initiatives to advance earth-surface process modeling across many disciplines, and 3) educational products and training workshops aimed at various entry levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All 7.6 billion of us live on Earth’s dynamic surface, where our lives are vulnerable to geologic processes ranging from landslides to coastal erosion to ﬂoods. The potential impacts of these process include devastation of infrastructure and loss of life. The consequences of these events (both short-term events and slow-onset changes that impact landscapes and coasts) are increasingly overwhelming available resources for communities of all sizes. Extreme events caused more than $50 billion in damage during each of the last 5 years in the United States. Even in the sparsely populated state of Alaska, surface changes caused by permafrost thaw, ﬂooding, and coastal erosion were recently estimated to be a $4–5 billion infrastructure problem for the 21st century. Improved understanding and prediction of these processes, as well as better knowledge of their role in shaping Earth’s surface over geologic time, requires computational modeling. Decision-makers need robust, accurate predictions of future impacts to increase our resiliency and live sustainably in an ever-changing world. 

 

This project provided continuing support for the Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS), an organization that provides researchers with software and hardware technology for computer simulation of geologic processes. CSDMS helps catalyze idea generation and analysis, enabling the rapid creation and application of computer simulation models tailored to specific settings, scientific problems, and time scales. Our unique community approach allows the efficient development of models that are more powerful than could be developed by any single group. As a result, redundancy is reduced, models are better vetted, the capacity for innovation is expanded, and energy can be focused towards the most pressing scientific questions. CSDMS makes modeling software accessible and transparent, by soliciting and publishing model documentation. In addition, the CSDMS Integration Facility team converts simulation models into modules that can be easily coupled together; this modularity lowers the barriers to learning and applying models, gives rise to new applications for existing software.

 

CSDMS streamlines the analysis of numerous societally relevant natural processes. Examples include flooding, melting glaciers, landsliding, erosion, wetland evolution, water cycling, and coastal change. Through its community support mechanisms, CSDMS brings together a diverse body of experts to better understand these processes. This project enabled CSDMS to launch new community initiatives to connect researchers across different scientific disciplines, and supported focused research on pressing scientific questions proposed by our research community. The results of CSDMS science are highlighted on its website and disseminated through publications. 

 

CSDMS supports and promotes diversity within the computational earth science community. We invite talented scientists from traditionally underrepresented communities to attend and speak at our meetings, and to lead workshops. 

 

Project activities can be divided into three areas: community, computing, and education. Examples of accomplishments in each of these areas are listed below:

 

Community

CSDMS catalyzed and supported new community initiatives to advance earth-­surface process modeling across disciplines. Six new community initiatives were pursued: 1) an earth-­ecosystem modeling initiative to capture ecosystem dynamics and their interaction with other processes on land and offshore, 2) a geodynamics initiative to investigate the interplay between earthquakes, mountain-building, and land-forming processes, 3) a human dimensions modeling initiative, to incorporate mechanistic models of human influences, 4) a coastal vulnerability modeling initiative, with emphasis on river deltas and their multiple threats and stressors, 5) a continental margin modeling initiative, to better understand how coastal processes and storms in the Gulf of Mexico combine to trigger turbidity currents, which threaten offshore infrastructure, and 6) a Critical Zone focus research group, to develop compatibility between CSDMS technology and the data and models developed through other NSF investments in Critical-Zone science. CSDMS also conducted capacity building and community networking through annual meetings and maintained and enriched open-source software repositories (including simulation models, tools, data, and educational resources).

Computing

CSDMS has produced transformative software products and approaches designed to be accessible, easy to use, and relevant. These include the development and dissemination of protocols for open-source model development and best coding practices, a web-based GUI to run standalone or coupled model simulations, and service tools that support the evaluation of computer simulation models of various earth-surface processes. CSDMS has promoted efficiency by advancing the practice of community model-software reuse, including model coupling through advanced architecture, language-neutral compilers, and a component-based framework designed for plug-and-play model simulations. CSDMS also supported a shared high-performance computing system for community members’ research and teaching initiatives.

Education

CSDMS has provided training opportunities to hundreds of community members, including graduate students, undergraduate students, and early-career scientists, through hands-on workshops. In addition, CSDMS develops, compiles, and curates a rich library of digital educational resources, including animated movies showing model simulations, video-recorded lectures, slides, laboratory exercises, and “science on a sphere” videos. These materials are shared openly on the CSDMS web portal.
